benchmark_details.name: Medical Visual Hallucination Test (MedVH)
benchmark_details.overview: The MedVH benchmark dataset is designed to evaluate the hallucination of domain-specific Large Vision Language Models (LVLMs) in the medical context, comprising five tasks that assess visual and textual understanding along with long text generation.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To systematically evaluate the hallucination capabilities of LVLMs in the medical context.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: Existing models show susceptibility to hallucinations despite accuracy in standard tasks.
out_of_scope_uses: General application outside of medical context

data.source: Constructed from various publicly available datasets including MIMIC-CXR, RAD-VQA, and others.
data.size: 500 questions from four public medical VQA datasets.
data.annotation: Medical text and images with corresponding questions and answers.

methodology.calculation: Characterization score is a weighted harmonic mean of hallucination accuracy and baseline accuracy.
methodology.interpretation: Higher scores indicate better resistance to hallucinations while maintaining accuracy.
methodology.validation: Comparison with existing benchmarks (e.g., MC-VQA tasks).

targeted_risks.harm: Susceptibility to hallucinations can lead to misdiagnosis or inappropriate treatment plans.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.privacy_and_anonymity: All patient data has been anonymized to comply with HIPAA standards.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.data_licensing: Dataset constructed from publicly available sources.
